title: Case 7 – The Missing Ledger
brief:
An accountant disappears into the basement boiler rooms and never walks back up. His briefcase held a ledger — names, bribes, debts, the city's bloodstream of favours.
Only three workers signed into that concrete maze:

BEN — crate carrier, muscle for the depot.
ISSAC — technician with a key to every power box.
PETER — riverwalk engineer, first signature of the night.

The boilers kept hissing. The accountant never resurfaced.
The ledger left with someone else.
wrenHint:
Paper trails never lie — only the people holding them do.

• Peter signs in twice: one crisp entry, one smeared like a rush exit.
• Ben claims the crate was empty — yet sweated hauling it downstairs.
• Issac’s toolkit is dusty, untouched, like he arrived and thought better.

Someone used 'maintenance' as cover to disappear a man… and a book worth fortunes.

ben: I carried the crate like the manifest told me to. Empty as my wallet. Heavy only because the stairwell is narrow and I'm built for loading bays, not ladders.
The accountant yelled at me once about boxes blocking his hall. Thin man. Loud voice. Not someone you remember fondly.
If you find my prints on the crate or briefcase, it's from pushing them aside to get the cart through. Secrets aren’t my business — freight is.
issac: Lights were dead when I arrived. No hum from the transformers, no glow from the boiler gauges. Working in pitch black is for thrill-seekers, not licensed engineers.
We argued once over numbers — he wanted me to 'adjust' readings to make inefficiencies vanish. I told him electricity isn't magic. He preferred someone who’d fake sparks.
Fingerprints on the panel? That proves I opened it. Nothing more. I left the job half-done and half-paid. The ledger was his mess, not mine.
peter: Boilers run hot that night. I took my readings, wrote them down, and planned to return later. Nothing unusual — routine work.
He hired me privately before. Wanted 'efficiency' without paperwork. I smelled trouble. Ledger like that — it tracks who owes who, and who needs to vanish.
He handed me the briefcase to move away from the heat — leather cracks near steam. I set it down. After that… well, someone must've wanted the book more than breath.

successEnding:
{culprit} folds when you show the second signature.

Two sign-ins, one exit. A heavy 'empty' crate, perfect size for a briefcase and a frightened accountant. The smeared log — signed in haste. Peter knew the ledger burned hotter than any boiler.
He walked out calm and lighter by one book.

When cuffs close, he whispers, 'Everyone pays eventually'.
failureEnding:
You pin it on {accused} — the crate boy, the technician, any man near the steam.
They crack under pressure, or give up fighting it.

Then Wren calls. Smudged signature, false maintenance request, crate weight mismatch — every line leads back to {culprit}.

The ledger resurfaces weeks later in whispers and bribes, pages torn, names missing.
Justice heats slow — but the wrong man cools in a cell.
